_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Petroleum and Petroleum Products Merchant Wholesalers (except Bulk Stations and Terminals)
Petroleum and Petroleum Products Merchant Wholesalers (except Bulk Stations and Terminals)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Limetree Bay Facility

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

REASON FOR SUBMISION

The reason for this submittal is the startup of specific Limetree Bay Refinery (LBR) process units in conjunction with Limetree Bay Terminal Facility. This facility was previously owned and operated by Hovensa, LLC (Hovensa), and it was shutdown in 2012. On January 4, 2016 LBR bought the facility and commence redesigning and upgrading some process units taking in considerations all RMP requirements.  The restart of specific refinery process units is forecasted for the period mid-June through the third quarter 2020, with the units included in this RMP submission.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The refinery provides employment for about 800 people (LBR and Contractor employees). Many of the employees, including senior officers of LBR, live in company housing adjacent to the refinery. The reconfigured refinery can process up to 200,000 barrels of crude oil per day, using a variety of processes to convert crude oil into various petroleum products (e.g., fuel oils, diesel, kerosene, jet fuel, gasoline and propane). The refinery has several regulated flammables, such as hydrogen, ethane, propane, butane, pentane, and one regulated toxic material which is anhydrous ammonia.  

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS Worst Case Scenario-Toxic 

The worst case scenario for anhydrous ammonia is failure of the ammonia storage drum containing approximately 110,000 pounds. The cloud formed from this release is expected to reach offsite receptors. Although numerous controls are in place to prevent such a release and to manage the consequences, no administrative controls (including release prevention measures) or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario. 

Alternative Release Scenario-Toxic 

The toxic alternative release scenario is an anhydrous ammonia leak in the flexible hose used to load ammonia from the tank truck into the

storage drum, resulting in a release of approximately 17,000 pounds. This scenario may reach offsite public receptors. Also, it assumes that LBR personnel will stop the release within 30 minutes. No administrative controls (including release prevention measures) or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario. 

Worst Case Scenario-Flammables 

Three worst-case scenarios involving flammable substances were identified.

The first worst case scenario is a failure of the one of two east butane storage sphere containing approximately 5,300,000 pounds of liquid butane, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The second worst case scenario is a failure of one of three west butane storage sphere containing approximately 5,000,000 pounds of liquid butane, also resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. 



Under certain circumstances, these scenarios could reach offsite public receptors. The vapor cloud explosion analyses were performed utilizing DNV Technica's PHAST dispersion software, and Baker-Strehlow blast overpressure method as employed by Wilfred Baker Engineering, Inc. Although numerous controls are in place to prevent such releases and to manage the consequences, no administrative controls (including release prevention measures) or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating these scenarios. 





Alternative Release Scenario-Flammables

The alternative release scenario for flammable substances is a leak in the liquid pump associated with the Frationation tower overhead receiver pump at D-4104 overhead receiver,   resulting in a release of approximately 5,200 lbs per hour pentane and lighter material .The released ignites, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. 

The vapor cloud explosion analyses were performed utilizing DNV Technica's PHAST dispersion software, and Baker-Strehlow blast overpressure method as employed by Wilfred Baker Engineering, Inc. The total quantity released assumes LBR personnel will stop the

release within 30 minutes. No administrative controls (including release prevention measures) or passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this scenario. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES 

LBR is commitment to the safety of employees, public safety and the surrounding environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training employees and implementing safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of its processes. The company's policy is to protect the community and its workers from accidental releases of chemical substances and to reduce the extent and impact of a release. However, if a release does occur, personnel are trained to respond, control, contain, and mitigate the release. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the LBR refinery. Processes at the refinery, which are regulated by the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule, are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. This summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program. 

Employee Participation 

LBR requires employees to participate in all facets of their PSM and accident prevention program. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents. developing operating procedures and chemical information, and participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the refinery accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the refinery and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, t

he refinery has the following initiatives under way that address process safety and LBR and contractor employee safety issues:

?    JSA - Job safety analysis - audits.

?    Review and update all personal and process safety procedures.

?    Extensive training programs for operators and maintenance personnel.

These initiatives are being developed by different teams to further promote both process and personal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering, plant management and/or contractors. 





Process Safety Information 

LBR keeps a variety of technical documents used to maintain safe operation of each process. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. (Specific departments, i.e. Maintenance, Engineering, Safety, Reliability, within the refinery are assigned responsibility to maintaining up-to-date process safety information). A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate necessary process safety information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDS) and HAZCOM list for each unit. The refinery ensures that each process is maintained within acceptable operating limits, by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automatic shutdown systems). 

LBR maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of each process units and associated equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature ratings, area electrical classification, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures

and trained personnel, provide a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised. 

Process Hazard Analysis 

LBR has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage such hazards. 

The primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis, ""What-If"', or PHA checklist technique to perform these evaluations. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating, technical and maintenance experience, as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates process hazards along with accident prevention and mitigation measures and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. 

The PHA team findings are forwarded to the various departments (i.e., Operations, Technical & Engineering, Reliability, and Maintenance). Resolution implementation of mitigation options, in response to PHA findings, is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This risk ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained. 

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate from the original design safety features, LBR periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency throughout the life of each process. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team finding

s are forwarded to the corresponding departments (i.e., Operations, Technical & Engineering, Reliability, and Maintenance) for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained. The results of the PHA findings are reviewed with appropriate employees/contractors. 







Operating Procedures 

LBR maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) generic operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) initial startup of a new process.  Update of the procedure included, but not limited to, Platformer start up procedure with electrolytic hydrogen as no hydrogen will be available from the other Platformers; revision of all procedures for units with furnaces to address refractory curing; new heaters operations with low NOx burners; hydrotreaters will have new sulfiding procedures. These procedures are referenced by certified operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are certified annually, or as often as necessary to ensure that they are current and accurate. 

In addition, LBR maintains key process parameter documents that provide guidance on how to respond to abnormal operating conditions. This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks. 

Training 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, LBR has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New process operators receive basic training in refinery operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing such training, a new operator is paired with a senior certified operator to learn process- specific duties and tasks. When operators demonstrate proficient knowledge (e.g., through knowledge tests and performance

tests) to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are certified to operate the corresponding unit independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training (re-certification) on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least once every 3 years. All operator training is documented, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 

Contractors 

LBR uses contractors to supplement its work force. Some contractors work on or near process equipment; therefore, the refinery (1) informs contractors of hazards known to the refinery which are related to the contractor's work and the processes in the area of such work; (2) makes sure that the contractor understands what to do in the event of an emergency; (3) develops and implements safe work practices, such as permit systems, to control contractor entrance, presence and exit from the process areas; (4) provides the contractor with site safety rules and applicable safe operating practice procedures; and (5) requires that contractors inform site safety personnel of hazards they encounter. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, LBR evaluates contractor safety programs and performance as a part of the contractor selection process. Also, refinery personnel periodically monitor and evaluate contractor performance to verify that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations once onsite. 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

LBR conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are

appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to confirm construction on equipment modifications are in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 

Mechanical Integrity 

LBR has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections/tests and documenting results, (4) preventive maintenance, (5) correcting identified deficiencies, and (6) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable operating limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a Management of Change (MOC) team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necess

ary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. LBR incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs such as the Repair Stamp Program. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

Safe Work Practices 

LBR has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) process unit control entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tag-out procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed in a safe manner. 

Management of Change 

LBR has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with the necessary training regarding the change. 

Incident Investigation 

LBR promptly inve

stigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or a personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to the refinery management for approval. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are completed. 

The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHA studies. 





Compliance Audits 

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, LBR conducts a PSM audit, at least every three years, to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed, and the final resolution of each finding is documented. The two most recent audit reports are retained. 

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

The processes at LBR have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The Program 3 prevention program requirements are applied to all RMP-covered processes at LBR refinery. 

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, LBR has general safety features on all process units to help (1) prevent a release, (2) contain/control a release, (3) quickly detect a release, and/or (4) reduce the consequence

s of (mitigate) a release. The following types of general safety features are used in various processes: 

Release Detection

Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms Release Prevention/Containment/Control 

? Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

? Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automatic)

? Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

? Allow for partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release

? Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

? Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., non-interruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pumps) 

Release Mitigation 

?    Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

?    Deluge system for specific equipment

?    Trained emergency response personnel

?    Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

?    Equipment spacing that limits hazard exposure 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

For this submittal, LBR has not operated before; therefore, the facility has not experienced a RMP covered incident(s), there is no incident history.  In the event that the facility experience a covered incident, the same will investigate very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

LBR maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion, if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release oc

curs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. 

In addition, LBR has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated, if applicable, when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or changes involving refinery personnel. The emergency response procedure changes are administered and include informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes. 

The overall emergency response program for LBR is handled by trained company personnel. The St. Croix US Virgin Island - Department of Plan and Natural Resources (DPNR) in charge of organizing Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and VITEMA - Virgin Islands Territorial Emergency Management Administration are notified if the emergency might affect the public. 

Although local agencies may assist with onsite emergency response, LBR's ability to respond does not depend on such assistance. LBR has 24-hour communication capabilities with appropriate DPNR officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., VITEMA - Virgin Islands Territorial Management Administration). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. LBR conducts periodic emergency planning meetings that involve the DPNR and emergency response organizations,
